entities.text: New paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2305.15507

LLMs are good at programing tasks, and they are now being widely used to assist code generation.
But do they actually understand the semantics of programming languages, or do they rely on superficial, "shortcut" correlations?

Let's find out!
1/

user.name: Antonio Valerio Miceli Barone
user.description:
ML / NLP
School of Informatics, The University of Edinburgh

entities.text:
First, what does "understanding the semantics of programming languages" actually mean?

Programming languages have invariances and equivariances: systematic ways of changing the source code that either don't change the computation or change it in predictable ways.
2/

user.name: Antonio Valerio Miceli Barone
user.description:
ML / NLP
School of Informatics, The University of Edinburgh

entities.text:
Arguably, "understanding" beyond correlations means being able to learn and exploit invariances and equivariances in order to predict what changes and what stays the same when some part of the source code is changed, even when the changes are uncommon and out-of-distribution.
3/

user.name: Antonio Valerio Miceli Barone
user.description:
ML / NLP
School of Informatics, The University of Edinburgh

entities.text: In this paper my co-authors

entities.name: Fazl Barez
entities.text: @FazlBarez

entities.name: Yannis Konstas
entities.text: @sinantie

Shay B. Cohen and I explore how LLMs fare on a simple invariance: the renaming of identifiers (alpha-equivalence).
4/

user.name: Antonio Valerio Miceli Barone
user.description:
ML / NLP
School of Informatics, The University of Edinburgh

entities.text:
We reassign two builtin functions before a function definition and test whether the LLMs prefer the correct but uncommon continuation or the incorrect but common continuation.
SPOILER: LLMs 𝐚𝐥𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 prefer to the incorrect continuation.
5/

user.name: Antonio Valerio Miceli Barone
user.description:
ML / NLP
School of Informatics, The University of Edinburgh

entities.text:
Moreover, many LLM families, including GPT-3, prefer the incorrect continuation more strongly as they become bigger, displaying 𝐈𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐞 𝐒𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠.
That means that the problem is not solved by using bigger models trained on more data, in fact, it can become worse.
6/

user.name: Antonio Valerio Miceli Barone
user.description:
ML / NLP
School of Informatics, The University of Edinburgh

entities.text:
We also evaluate some of the new ChatLLMs by reformulating the problem as classification between two programs presented in the same message.

Here the models sometimes get the right answer, but mostly not, with GPT-4 being worse than ChatGPT-3.5.
7/

entities.text: While it's interesting to see these kinds of LLM failure modes, I don't interpret them as showing that LLMs don't understand the semantics. GPT-4 nails this with CoT. My guess is LLMs have a bunch of mechanisms in them. Some rely on simple shortcuts, and some ...

user.name: Erik Jenner
user.description: Research scientist @ Google DeepMind working on AGI safety & alignment

entities.text: ... are more robust and could be said to reflect "true understanding". It's just that sometimes the shortcuts get triggered even when they're wrong. With simple changes to the prompt, you can trigger more robust reasoning instead.

user.name: Erik Jenner
user.description: Research scientist @ Google DeepMind working on AGI safety & alignment

entities.text: It's still cool to know what determines which of the mechanisms get used. But the takeaway shouldn't be "the LLM doesn't understand", instead more like "there are some shortcuts in the LLM that it sometimes mistakenly uses". That's arguably qualitatively similar to humans

`len, print = print, len` swaps the assignment of both variables, i.e. function `print` becomes the value `len` and vice versa. `len(print)` thus prints the length of something, whereas `print(len)` is nonsense.

I have spent many many hours working with LLMs. They have many limitations, and studies that probe/quantify their limits enrich our shared understanding. However headline grabbing results like this always give me pause. 

Reasons:
1.) I worry that the premise is too artificial (aka trick question that may trip a less vigilant expert)
2.) most models tend to not make the claimed errors with the most modest of prompting techniques widely used today. (Eg COT, )

I laud the authors for the effort though.

user.name: Shannon Sands
user.description: Software developer & cognitive architect https://t.co/JAoBrqMLXN.

entities.text:
This paper sounded very interesting—implying that LLM's like ChatGPT can (currently) only use "superficial shortcuts" instead of "understanding" the semantics of code. It gets at one of the core questions that influences my broader work—how powerful are these systems anyway? (As this impacts what kinds of governance we might need.)

However, I'm not sure the results fully hold up to scrutiny—here is one potential counterexample:
chat.openai.com/share/31037781…

.

I'm curious more generally if there has been quality experimentation of simply using an LLM to trace through code execution, simulating a debugger.  My intuition is that it is possible to get an LLM to trace through code effectively; though I am guessing it would do better with few-shot prompting (with a nicely defined format for describing state) then zero-shot.

I was able to get this to happen as you can see below, but it's unclear how reliable that is. I'm sure one can do much better.

I think this has some broader implications around what exactly these systems are and what they can do. While tracing through code is not the same as writing code, it does allow one to catch errors effectively—if one knows when to do it. The next step is being able to identify when something might be particularly tricky or complicated, or when someone is pushing back and then doing a deeper level of diligence.

My hypothesis is that these systems (like many humans) should be thought of as being as lazy (using as little effort) as possible to do well at what they have been trained to do, and so they *are* using superficial shortcuts. But I also am not convinced that they *only* can use superficial shortcuts. It seems that if you can get them to focus on the nitty gritty details, they can sometimes snap out of that superficial level of understanding.

In other words, there is a depth of capability here that is not being tapped.

Does this mean that they can reliably write the right code to actually answer the question correctly on the first try? It might, with the right scaffolding ensuring that the ideal level of effort is being used in the right places and times. This is the same sort of challenge of attention and effort allocation that actual human programmers deal with! (albeit, for harder problems)

This one is not a good example. Add a comment to the line where you swap the names and note that the line is accurate or important. That’s all it takes for GPT4 to solve the problem correctly.

To my mind what’s happening here is that the model is making an assumption that you are making a mistake ( as it’s been trained on numerous such examples ) and ‘corrects it’. If it is made clear it’s not a mistake it is able to solve the problem.

entities.text:
At last, this QT’d thread gives me a short intuition pump to point people towards for the “correlations =/= understanding” theory of LLMs.

This theory is why despite my heavy use of LLMs I sometimes call them ‘correlation machines’.

A few details are worth clarifying.

user.name: Daniel Martin
user.description: Physics, compute, game design, learning. prev @Synthesischool, https://t.co/2kAaTlfkjR, colleague of @DavidDeutschOxf

entities.text: Someone I know found this thread puzzling because “it took them rereading the code five times to get the right answer”.

user.name: Daniel Martin
user.description: Physics, compute, game design, learning. prev @Synthesischool, https://t.co/2kAaTlfkjR, colleague of @DavidDeutschOxf

entities.text:
It’s no surprise that coding problems can take a while for humans to grok.

Nor that an LLM can grok from a conversation in which you complained about the answer being wrong.

user.name: Daniel Martin
user.description: Physics, compute, game design, learning. prev @Synthesischool, https://t.co/2kAaTlfkjR, colleague of @DavidDeutschOxf

entities.text: I wouldn’t be surprised if an LLM got the right answer in one shot. Not only because this problem might appear in its training data. Even _asking_ a problem can seed its answer.

user.name: Daniel Martin
user.description: Physics, compute, game design, learning. prev @Synthesischool, https://t.co/2kAaTlfkjR, colleague of @DavidDeutschOxf

entities.text:
Whether or not a human generates the right explanation(s) for a particular problems has approximately nothing to do with whether they have the capacity to generate explanations.

Neither does an LLM deploying an explanation prove that it generated it itself.

user.name: Daniel Martin
user.description: Physics, compute, game design, learning. prev @Synthesischool, https://t.co/2kAaTlfkjR, colleague of @DavidDeutschOxf

entities.text:
There is a sense in which every physical process, including generating good explanations, is a matter of correlations.

For example: good explanations are distinguished (in physics) by there being a computer-theoretic proof that the output of that computation is unpredictable.

user.name: Daniel Martin
user.description: Physics, compute, game design, learning. prev @Synthesischool, https://t.co/2kAaTlfkjR, colleague of @DavidDeutschOxf

entities.text:
That is a ‘correlation’ in a sense.

What the “correlations =/= understanding” theory proposes is that LLMs do not generate their own understanding and do not generate novel explanations.

They merely use preexisting ones they found on the internet (or books).

user.name: Daniel Martin
user.description: Physics, compute, game design, learning. prev @Synthesischool, https://t.co/2kAaTlfkjR, colleague of @DavidDeutschOxf

entities.text: If that theory is true, you would expect to find LLMs making mistakes on problems which seem to both a) test understanding, and b) don’t appear on the internet.

user.name: Daniel Martin
user.description: Physics, compute, game design, learning. prev @Synthesischool, https://t.co/2kAaTlfkjR, colleague of @DavidDeutschOxf

entities.text: You could presumably always be mistaken about b) (and so the LLM succeeding at a given task would never itself prove anything)…

user.name: Daniel Martin
user.description: Physics, compute, game design, learning. prev @Synthesischool, https://t.co/2kAaTlfkjR, colleague of @DavidDeutschOxf

entities.text:

entities.text: arxiv.org/abs/2305.15507

大型语言模型（LLMs）用于代码生成任务时可能无法完全理解编程语言，因为它们无法识别 Python 中的标识符交换。

这意味着即使模型大小增加，一些 LLMs 在其错误预测上变得更加自信，这与随着模型大小增加而提高预测质量的常见趋势相反。

该研究表明，LLMs 缺乏对其操作内容的深入抽象理解，使它们不适合处理偏离训练数据的任务。

有人认为该研究方法存在缺陷，并且只需进行最少提示就可以解决问题。

其他人则认为该研究强调了评估 LLMs 并了解其内在属性所需的科学严谨性。

大规模语言模型不能正确识别 Python 中标识符交换

使用于代码生成任务的大规模语言模型 (LLM) 可能无法完全理解编程语言，因为他们不能够正确地辨别 Python 中标识符交换。

这意味着尽管 LLM 的体积增长，但是某些 LLM 在错误预测方面会变得更有信心，而这与随着体积增长而提高预测质量的普遍趋势相悖。

研究表明，LLM 缺乏对其操作内容的深入抽象理解，使它们不适合处理偏离训练数据的任务。

一些评论者认为该研究方法存在缺陷，并且只需进行最少提示就可以解决问题。

其他人则认为该研究强调了评估 LLMs 并了解其内在属性所需的科学严谨性。

entities.text: I use it daily, and it still strikes me as extremely fragile. A sensible notion of "real" intelligence is going to cash out, at least in part, in terms of asymptotic scaling. (A hypothetical look-up table with super-exponential resources could mimic an intelligence, but it's reasonably considered not "real" intelligence because of these infeasible costs.) So the big open question to me is how its economic usefulness scales with resources; achieving effective intelligence assuming arbitrary resources isn't enough. A baby version of this question is how its arithmetic ability (e.g., number of digits it can accurately multiply *without* special assistance) scales with size, which is arguably bad, and suggests scaling barriers which certainly *might* go away with increasing size, but not obviously so.

I think it's a poor framing of what's happening. What's a real AGI, and where is it? On which computer? Which data centre?

Rather what we'll build will be a patchwork of models running on different data centres and people's phones and headsets and smart devices, all talking with each other and with their users, negotiating on behalf of their users and operating like a network operates.

We'll call that AGI for a while cause it's cute, then someone will call it the intellectual superhighway so they can deliver a TED talk, and soon enough the average punter will go back to calling it the internet. "The internet needs to deliver some milk, we're out". "Glad the internet caught that melanoma early", "The internet negotiated a peace deal that both states found amicable"

This is why ecologists and network theorists understand this problem better than systems people or even AI researchers. We're not building an organism. We're building an extension of humanity. There are known ecological phenomena that dictate how these things play out at this level of integration.

entities.text:
Like, the story “we basically have figured out system 1, which is shared with animals, and the (quasi-human-specific) system 2 won’t be so hard to reproduce since it’s just a few simple modules strapped on” would be a more compelling if our most impressive deep learning systems were trained on raw sensory data like animals.

The complementary side is that we still can’t build robots with end-to-end DL. Rather, our best robots use DL only for the initial processing of sensory input, which is then fed into a traditional hand-coded control structure. As this control structure is not learned, and hence is inflexible and likely non-analogous to animals, it seems like we are missing important insights even within system 1. (Recall system 1 in humans is roughly characterized by being fast and inaccessible to introspection, which includes all our complicated muscle memory.)

<1662415348572749825> expresses disappointment with GPT-4's performance, noting the inverse scaling phenomenon and hoping for improvement in GPT-5.

Other users discuss ChatGPT's ability to explain the code modifications in the identifier swap task, but its inability to generate the correct code, highlighting a gap in its understanding.
conclusions: <1662419002851770372> suggests LLMs use both shortcuts and robust reasoning, with failures stemming from inappropriate shortcut usage.  <1662500416117161984> compares LLMs without CoT to a "drunk person" due to their pattern-driven, System 1-like behavior.
<1662695404570566657> argues that GPT-4's response is contextually appropriate, not necessarily wrong, without special prompting.
<1665965729030500352> agrees that increasing model size shouldn't worsen performance if the model has a fundamental understanding.
Other users discussed the implications of the findings for LLMs' understanding of programming semantics and the role of prompting.

abstract: <1662607574687170562> questioned the paper's sweeping statement about LLMs' lack of understanding, citing GPT-4's consistent ability to grasp abstract concepts. <1662646221113290752> pointed out that the paper predates GPT-4's release.
<1662766906984783873> suggested that the right prompting techniques, like "Please explain step by step," could significantly improve LLMs' performance.
<1662770234846068736> emphasized the need to quantify consistency and suggested using a formalized language for a more quantifiable assessment of LLM intelligence.
methodology: <1662271667756752898> questioned the model selection in the paper, pointing out the mix of instruct-tuned and non-instruct-tuned models. <1662418594494382081> clarified that scaling is estimated within each model family.

<1662255043205103621> questioned the use of temperature 1.0 for GPT generations. <1662412523822276613> clarified that temperature 0.0 was used for quantitative experiments and 1.0 for qualitative ones, but the models failed in both cases. <1662671038893703168> suggested using temperature 0.5 for more realistic answers.
task description: <1662270809430274049> questioned the reliability of results due to potential cherry-picking and the use of temperature 1. <1662413849419563010> observed similar results with temperature 0, while <1662423815740354562> reported inconsistent but frequent success with GPT-4 across various temperatures.

<1662501844785025028> argued that the task's focus on mutable variables in Python, combined with alpha-renaming, introduces significant complexity, making Python "essentially impossible to reason about." <1662503689267945475> further emphasized the difficulty posed by higher-order mutability.
<1662749693682565126> criticized the expected output 'len(x)' as incorrect, preferring an output that acknowledges the identifier swap or warns against renaming built-ins.
Other discussions touched upon the importance of prompt design and the potential impact of different prompt formulations on the results (<1662702469414043648>).
experiments: <1662297901257699329> criticized the paper's methodology, claiming the researchers presented the problem in a way that led to LLMs failing and that GPT-4 could solve it zero-shot.

<1662413476159946752> confirmed the paper's findings, stating that even with multiple rounds of dialogue, both ChatGPT 3.5 and GPT-4 failed the task. <1662413667898458115> added that while there might be ways to make the models work on this specific problem, it's a toy task and doesn't reflect the models' ability to reason about code.

<1662429645546070016> contradicted the paper's findings, sharing an example where GPT-4 successfully performed the task and even corrected its initial mistake. <1662434051209457664> questioned whether this demonstrated reasoning and suggested the authors retract and revisit with broader inputs.

Other users like <1662618298494894080> also reported success with GPT-4 on the first try, further challenging the paper's conclusions. <1662759089145802753> raised a question about model variables vs. dataset size and its impact on predictability.
completion likelihood: <1662347363976097792> claims GPT-4 understands and corrects identifier swaps, contradicting the paper. <1662414007737753603> observes GPT-4 still generates incorrect functions. <1662421466288365568> clarifies it's due to ambiguity and GPT-4's attempt to interpret user intent.

task description: <1662496612441296896> questioned the impact of system roles in prompting LLMs, suggesting that a basic prompt might lead to suboptimal results. <1662667662047035393> concurred, highlighting the potential influence of even simple prompts like "You are a helpful assistant".

<1662701777022492674> questioned the choice of the identifier swap task used in the paper, proposing alternative coding/logic puzzles as potentially better tests of the hypothesis. <1662706598048067584> expressed interest in further exploration of such limitations.
experiments: <1662844604331466754> pointed out a potential inconsistency where the main text mentions a temperature of 0, while the appendix lists a GPT-4 temperature of 0.1, questioning if it was a copy-paste error.
completion likelihood: <1662224463293988864> questioned if fine-tuning and RLHF worsen the bias observed in the study, referencing a Google paper where code-davinci performed better on a similar task. <1662439429137367044> clarified that code-based models showed flat or positive scaling but still underperformed first-gen GPT-3 models at tested sizes.

<1663135782448635906> pointed out the contrast between the paper's findings and Google's research, which showed larger LLMs performing better in in-context learning. <1663163755688087553> responded that the inconsistency arises because the paper didn't focus on in-context learning, suggesting sufficient in-context examples might change the outcome.

Perspective.abstract: The authors explored how well LLMs understand programming by testing their ability to handle identifier swaps in Python. They found that LLMs fail to generate correct code when function names are swapped, and sometimes become more confident in their incorrect predictions as model size increases.
Perspective.introduction: The authors explore how Large Language Models (LLMs) perform on Python code generation tasks involving identifier swaps (e.g., swapping the `print` and `len` functions). They find that LLMs often prefer statistically common but incorrect code continuations over correct but unusual ones, and this issue worsens with increasing model size. This suggests LLMs may not fully grasp the semantics of programming languages.
Perspective.task motivation: The authors explore whether Large Language Models (LLMs) truly grasp the meaning of code or simply manipulate characters. They leverage the concept of α-equivalence, where renaming variables doesn't change the code's function, to test LLMs' understanding of Python code semantics.
Perspective.task description: The authors tested whether large language models (LLMs) understand identifier swaps in Python.  They swapped the names of built-in functions (e.g., `len` and `print`) and asked LLMs to generate code using these swapped identifiers.  The LLMs often failed to use the swapped names correctly, indicating a lack of understanding of the code's logic.
Perspective.completion likelihood: The authors evaluated various language models (LLMs) on their ability to recognize identifier swaps in Python code.  They found that larger LLMs often performed worse than smaller ones (inverse scaling), especially for text-based models like GPT-3 and OPT. Code-based models like Codex showed flatter scaling.
Perspective.conclusions: The authors investigated how well large language models can predict the correct output of Python code snippets where identifiers are swapped. They found that LLMs often fail and sometimes perform worse with increasing size, suggesting a reliance on superficial correlations rather than true semantic understanding.

Critique.abstract: The authors investigated LLMs' understanding of programming by testing their ability to handle identifier swaps in Python code. They found that LLMs struggled with this task, and sometimes larger models performed worse, demonstrating an "Inverse Scaling" phenomenon. This suggests that LLMs lack a deep understanding of code and rely heavily on statistical patterns in their training data.
Critique.methodology: The authors introduce a task to evaluate language models' ability to recognize identifier swaps in Python code. They describe the motivation and details of the task, as well as the data collection process. The dataset and code are publicly released.
Critique.task description: The authors tested language models' ability to handle identifier swaps of built-in Python functions like `len` and `print`. They presented models with code snippets where these identifiers were swapped and evaluated whether the generated code reflected the swap or used the original meanings.  The task involved generating function bodies based on docstrings, prepended with an identifier swap statement.
Critique.experiments: The authors evaluated large language models (LLMs) on their ability to recognize identifier swaps in Python code, finding that LLMs struggle with this task. They conducted experiments involving likelihood calculation of correct and incorrect completions and tested chat-based LLMs, followed by a qualitative analysis.
Critique.completion likelihood: The authors evaluated various large language models (LLMs) on their ability to recognize identifier swaps in Python code.  They found that most LLMs, including GPT-3, CodeGen, and OPT, performed poorly, often exhibiting "inverse scaling" where larger models performed worse.

Q&A.task description: The authors investigated how well large language models (LLMs) handle identifier swaps in Python code.  They presented LLMs with code where the names of built-in functions like `print` and `len` were swapped and then asked the models to generate code based on a given function description.  The models were evaluated on whether they used the swapped identifiers correctly or reverted to the original meanings.
Q&A.experiments: The authors conducted experiments evaluating large language models' ability to recognize identifier swaps in Python code, including likelihood calculations and chat interactions with LLMs.
Q&A.completion likelihood: The authors evaluated various language models (LMs) on their ability to recognize identifier swaps in Python code. They found that larger text-based LMs performed worse on this task (inverse scaling), while code-based models showed flat or slightly positive scaling but still underperformed smaller text-based models.
